DOC.HEAD: South Korea's Chun to Testify on Misdeeds before Parliament
DOC.TEXT: Disgraced former President Chun Doo-hwan will testify before parliament on corruption, human rights abuses and misconduct during his 7-year rule before the year ends, the governing party said Tuesday. South Korean politics have been dogged by public demands to clear the legacies of Chun's authoritarian rule so the way could be cleared for a more open government and more democratic reforms. The Democratic Justice Party said Chun received a summons to testify in the National Assembly Dec. 31, along with a 123-page document listing questions the legislators wanted answered. Details of the procedure were still being discussed, a party spokesman said. Chun left office in February 1988 after turning over power to his former associate Roh Tae-woo, named president in national voting two months earlier. Chun's predecessor, Choi Kyu-hah, also was expected to testify before the assembly. Choi served briefly as a figurehead president in late 1979. He was succeeded by Chun, who seized power in an internal army coup. Roh and the three main opposition leaders agreed on Dec. 15 on resolving disputes over Chun's administration. Such compromise is rare in Korean politics, but political leaders have been under mounting public pressure to agree on the Chun-related issues in a bid to make a new start in 1990. Forty-eight people, including about a dozen Chun relatives, have been convicted of corruption and power abuse. Chun went into rural exile in November 1988 after apologizing to the nation for misrule and misconduct and surrendering $24 million in unused political funds. Amopng the questions Chun was expected to answer were those about his alleged role in using the military to quell a civil uprising in Kwangju in 1980. By official count 200 people were killed and more than 1,500 injured in the uprising. Radicals and dissidents have staged violent protests to demand that Chun be arrested and punished. The main opposition parties have publicly promised not to raise more Chun-related issues once their demands are met. Dissidents have denounced the agreement as a sellout.
